column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country- subject to vaccine status and origin.

Document checklist:
1. Passenger Locator Form: all travellers must fill it in within 6 months before entering Belgium. Important: To determine the quarantine measures, Please note that from 11 march, the PLF will now only be mandatory for people travelling with a carrier to Belgium from a third country that is not on the European Union’s whitelist. There is an exception when the person is traveling by specific travel means and staying less than 48 hours abroad, or less than 48 hours in Belgium. Persons who travel to Belgium by boat or plane are always obliged to fill in the Passenger Locator Form. The same applies to people who travel to Belgium by train or bus from outside the EU or Schengen area.
2. Proof of vaccination
Or
Proof of recovery. Validity: 180 days.
Or
Negative result to a pre-departure molecular test (valid 72 hours) or rapid antigen test (valid 36 hours).
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation
Entry rules
Entry requirements depend on the color attributed to the country of departure, according to Belgium own national classification of risk areas: green, orange, or red areas.
Children younger than 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.
column4:
THIS COUNTRY IS READY TO CONNECT TO THE EU DIGITAL COVID CERTIFICATE GATEWAY
Proof of full vaccination, completed at least two weeks before travelling. Accepted vaccines: vaccines authorised by the European Medicines Agency (EMA): Comirnaty (BioNTech and Pfizer), Moderna, Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca/Oxford), Janssen and Covidshield.
column5:
Latest News: Authorities will ease COVID-19 entry rules for travelers from European Union and Schengen Area countries from 11 March (SVI, 06.03.2022).

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU:

Documents equivalent to the ‘EU Digital COVID Certificate’ (EUDCC) in French and English are also accepted, if they meet the same requirements listed above for the EUDCC.

Learn more:

Arriving in Belgium

General information

National Health Institute


______________________

You can find the latest information on air travel regulations for this country on the IATA website.

You can also find information about your passenger rights on our portal for citizens.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



*Transit:

YES

Transit is considered essential travel and is therefore allowed.

Transit by air

Travellers who only transit by air and who only enter the transit zone are not required to present a negative test. However, these travellers are required to show a negative test certificate before arriving in Belgium if this is needed to travel on to their destination.

Transit by land

From within the EU+ area, if you will be spending less than 48 hours in Belgium and if you are not travelling by air or boat, no PCR test is required. The same applies also to cross-border workers. For people arriving in Belgium with their own vehicle, random checks may be carried out at the borders.

From outside the EU+ area, if you will be spending less than 48 hours in Belgium and if you are not travelling by air, boat, train or bus, no PCR test is required.



*From Third Countries:

Entry rules

Entry requirements depend on the color attributed to the country of departure, according to Belgium own national classification of risk areas: green, orange, red, dark red or grey areas.

Children younger than 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.

Document checklist:

Tavellers must provide all the following documents:

  1. Passenger Locator Form: all travellers must fill it in within 6 months before entering Belgium.
    • Important: To determine the quarantine measures, the PLF will take into consideration the areas where you have been in the 14 days before travelling. If the zones have changed colour, measures will apply retroactively.
    • There is an exception when the person is traveling by specific travel means and staying less than 48 hours abroad, or less than 48 hours in Belgium. Persons who travel to Belgium by boat or plane are always obliged to fill in the Passenger Locator Form. The same applies to people who travel to Belgium by train or bus from outside the EU or Schengen area.
  2. Proof of vaccination. Accepted vaccines: vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and Covidshield.

Or

Proof of recovery. Validity: 180 days.

Or

Negative result to a pre-departure molecular test (valid 72 hours) or rapid antigen test (valid 36 hours).

Learn more:


General information

National Health Institute


______________________

You can find the latest information on air travel regulations for this country on the IATA website.

You can also find information about your passenger rights on our portal for citizens.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



Internal Restrictions:
*Public spaces and services: The Belgian government has a number of measures in place to limit the spread of COVID-19. It is mandatory to wear face masks in the following indoor spaces for those above 12 years old:
• stores and shopping centres
• care establishments
• publicly accessible areas in businesses, companies, public buildings, courthouse buildings
• cultural and events venues, including in museums, cinemas, theatres and concert halls
• libraries, game/toy libraries and media libraries
• places of worship
• healthcare facilities, hairdressers, nail salons and other contact service providers
• public transport, including at stations and airports
Shops remain open but need to adhere to a ‘one customer per square metre’ rule. Customers will only be permitted to shop with one other person (not including minors).
Outdoor activities remain open but are subject to restricted capacity.
To enter into bars, restaurants, cafés, fitness centres and many other permitted indoor spaces and events, you will be required to demonstrate your COVID safe status through the Belgian Covid Safe Ticket (CST) system showing proof of vaccination, a recent negative test or a recovery certificate.
From 1 March 2022, those who have received a second vaccine dose (or, in the case of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, their sole dose) more than 150 days ago, will no longer count as fully vaccinated for domestic purposes within Belgium without a booster shot. Therefore they will need additional proof of Covid safe status (e.g. negative test, recovery certificate) to enter specific venues (e.g. restaurants and bars, cinemas, most museums, and many events).
These measures are kept under active review and are subject to an ongoing assessment of local conditions. There are also some regional differences in the implementation of measures. You should regularly check the website of the relevant city or town and the Belgian government advice website for the latest detailed information.
Accommodation: All types of accommodation are permitted to open subject to compliance with general rules related to COVID-19. Details are available on the Belgian Government website. Check with your accommodation provider for further information.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. Belgian authorities are likely to conduct calls to check you are quarantining. You may also need to seek treatment there.
